title.narrative: 2021 - 2026 Core programmatic support to monitor and safeguard an enabling environment for civil society

description.narrative: The Dutch Government's programmatic funding to CIVICUS contributes to the policy goal of monitoring and safeguarding an enabling environment for civil society of the Department for Social Development (DSO) (policy article 3.3 strengthening civil society). Besides, the proposed cooperation with CIVICUS fits in the policy goals as described in the policy letter to Parliament of the Minister for Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation of 9 October 2013. CIVICUS plays different roles as monitoring, lobbying, and convening, within the international discussion on enabling environment for civil society. CIVICUS has access to international networks and policy processes, and stimulates democratization of these processes. Besides, CIVICUS produces yearly, relevant and up-to-date research and monitoring reports. It is important for civil society worldwide and for the MFA that these roles and products are supported in order to maintain quality. Besides, the roles that CIVICUS plays are very complementary to the roles that the MFA plays and can increasingly play in international discussions. CIVICUS also complements the roles international and Dutch civil society play in capacity strengthening for both Lobby and Advocacy and for service delivery. CIVICUS tackles the basic conditions for civil society to operate at both national and international level.

recipient-country.narrative: CIVICUS' headquarters are based in Johannesburg, South Africa, but the organisation operates worldwide.

comment.narrative: The space for civil society to promote rights and pursue social justice has been historically contested. But presently, we’re seeing a greater range of states attacking civil society, the rise of anti-rights groups and a sharpening of tactics of restriction, including online attacks and censorship. Many contexts have seen political upheaval and a rejection of norms around the conduct of politics and democracy.

As a result of our efforts, groups most affected by the combined impact of structural discrimination and civic space restrictions are better supported in their efforts to mobilise change, which causes decision makers and institutions to act more responsibly to uphold civic and democratic freedoms. Public trust in civil society improves significantly and is reflected through increased solidarity with the work and priorities of civil society.

# 638 general media mentions + 46 CIVICUS references in OHCHR stakeholder document + 222 civic space reccommendations in UPR outcome documents, 10 statements + 1 letter to international governing bodies = 917 for Sept 1 – Dec 31, 2021 (mostly).
For the reporting period, July 1 – Sept 30, 2022: There were 638 general media mentions of CIVICUS for a collective r each of 900,000 readers according to MeltWater. In addition, there were 101 uses of the Monitor in media, academia, research institutes, INGO, and national CSOs. This is an improvement how?
For the reporting period, Oct 1 – Dec 31, 2022: There were 46 CIVICUS references in OHCHR stakeholder document from eight Produce Universal Periodic Review (UPR) Submissions for the following countries and number of respective references: Hungary (4), Papa New Guinea (6), Tanzania (5), Thailand (7), Timor-Leste (4), Togo (6), Uganda (1), and Venezuela (13). Furterhmore, there were 222 mentions # of civic space recommendations in outcome documents from the same eight (UPR) Submissions. The number of references of civic space in each outcome document for each country is as follows: Hungary (31), Papa New Guinea (4), Tanzania (31), Thailand (45), Timor-Leste (N/A or 0?), Togo (26), Uganda (32), and Venezuela (53). CIVICUS co-sponserd 10 statements and 1 letter to the UN Human Rights Council for the following countries Ethiopia, Nicaragua, Niger, Sudan, Phillipines, Cambodia, Congo, Paraguay, and Mozambique. Of these, three were quoted: Ethiopia, Nicaragua and Sudan. This influenced the decision-making process in the following ways: The Human Rights Council must establish a mechanism on Ethiopia (Adopted), the council must establish an investigation and accountability mechanism on Nicargua at its next Session , and the UN Human Rights Council should act urgently and hold a special session on Sudan.
